comments.commentBody: I listened to all the radio broadcasts on how the Yankees would win game 6.How Colby Lewis caught them off guard the first time and how they have figured out how to play him.Then I watch a team that only won two games due to errors and bullpen miscues by the Rangers, get clubbed again here in Texas.No one in New York thought this would happen and the Rangers have not gotten the credit they deserve for being a really good team that plays well together and believes they can beat anyone. They beat the No.1 and No.2 teams in the AL East and beat them in their own backyards with good pitching,base running, and hitting. I am happy for the Rangers because this is their first time and New York you need to recognize that your team was bashed not just beaten.History was not on the Yankees side this time.Good luck next year. Go Rangers!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
They can have Cashman, if they want.

Here's a thought

April 1 ages

38
41
39
36
35

you know their names, Yankees are old!

Thank you for this article!  I am going to print it out and keep copies to give to other women who try to get me to cut my hair.  I am 58 and my  hair is thick and dark brown with grey streaks.  It is currently at my waist, sometimes I let it get a bit longer.  Most men love it.  It's my women friends that have problems with it. I can see by the large number of comments, your article has caused quite a lot of feelings both ways. I think that women that have bought into the social "rule" that you must cut your hair short at a certain age lest you look too feminine (and yes, I understand that some women's hair gets thinner and won't grow long any more but many people cut their hair long before that happens) feel uncomfortable with those of us who haven't.  I even had one woman friend try to trick me into getting it cut. She said that her hairdresser was doing free haircuts for women with long hair for a week.  I asked some questions and it sounded like it wouldn't be just a trim so I said no thanks. But my daughter (then around 18 and also with long hair that she was going to cut for Locks of Love) was interested in the deal.  Oh, suddenly my friend stopped replying to the e-mail. Then I realized that she was going to pay her hairdresser to cut my hair.

My wife, a beautiful 47-year-old natural blond, has let her hair grow long, now past her shoulders, the past two years. She plans to let it grow until the end of this year, when she'll get it cut and donate the cuttings to Locks of Love. I just hope she doesn't cut it for another two years. I think she looks amazing in long hair, and always has.

Kelly, I know that shrub -- thank you, late, great Molly I! -- is no longer officially connected to the Rangers. But just seeing him there next to Nolan Ryan was enough for me. You're right, you're right. Anyway, this New Yorker's first priority now is; anyone but the Phillies.

good luck!

Well, I liver here in Old Hippieville and I see lots of women with long grey hair. On most of them I think it looks very good.  Every over-50 woman doesn't have thick healthy hair, but for those who do, why not?

I'm so lucky I had a mother who adored long hair as a teenager and still adores my long thick hair even though I am now 45.  I can count my grey hairs on one hand.  I don't know if I consider this 'luck' as I've been fantasising about grey / ash blond hair for 25 years!! I once saw the most beautiful women in Brooklyn NY with a thick grey plait down her back.  I've been fantasising about being that woman ever since but alas it looks as though I might have to wait another 25 years.

The Rangers have, on and off, been kind of the ignored professional sports franchise in DFW. They woke us all up a few years ago with obvious potential. This year, the pieces all fell into place.

The Ranger's insurgence this year has been great for Dallas-Ft Worth, and tonight's game was unquestionably one of the best sports moments in Dallas-Ft Worth's history. It ranks up there with any Cowboys Super Bowl win, Dallas Stars' Stanley Cup win, Dallas Mavericks playoffs wins. I rank it up there at the top with the Cowboys' Super Bowl win in 1992/1993.

Let this series loss go, Yankees fans. You team is full of smug, arrogant men, one of which is still on the Rangers' payroll! You were outcoached and outplayed by a team with a heck of alot more heart and with 1/4 of your team's payroll. Let us have the limelight for a while. Most of the country was rooting for us and for good reason. GO RANGERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Amateur announcers? Laugh at the ground crews? Is that the best NY fans can do?  As that old cliche goes, "he who laughs last..."

Major retooling needed for the Bombers. Time for the core four to go. Let's hope Cash (if he's still around) plays a little off-season smart moneyball, with an eye toward building a solid squad of talented if untested players, instead of trying to trying to buy the 2011 Championship.  Giving outragoeous contracts to crash and burn billion dollar babies just doesn't make sense. And get rid of Girardi...ASAP.
Who in their right mind would want to work for the Mets? It's kind of like working for the Knicks.

You just knew -- everybody knew -- that Cruz Control was going to jack one off Robertson.  It seemed so perfectly obvious to everyone except Girardi.  I agree with the one poster's comment that Cliff Lee is not a lock to go to the Yanks, and I hope he does stay with the Rangers.  Mariano is still the greatest but for how much longer?  He may decide that, besides the Rangers' superior left side of the infield, he'll have more games saved with Feliz.  On the other hand, he may be nothing more than a coldblooded mercenary.  In any event, good for the Rangers.  All the callers to WFAN today in NYC were so smug and self-assured about tonight's game...

I am a 46 year old physician with long, greying hair. I had a new patient (a stranger, really) ask me when I was going to cut my hair. "What makes you ask me that?" I said. "I just think women of a certain age should cut their hair short," was the reply.
I am convinced this issue is a rejection of midlife, female sexuality. Women with long hair represent (in an archetypal way, as the author states) sexiness. For some people, sexy is not for midlifers. And in this culture grey is akin to nearly dead. It's fun to flaunt it all: grey, sexed and happy with the blessing of living long enough to be called middle aged.

"Your description of the Steelers-Dophins matchup is a 200+ word diatribe on punishing hits. There is zero analysis of the teams' strengths and weaknesses. While I am pleased that you picked the Steelers, can't you use another blog to get on the soapbox?"

I disagree with this; I thought that segment was the best part of this week's blog post. If you want straightforward analysis of the upcoming games, look elsewhere, folks! There are plenty of other, more boring preview columns out there.

I'm glad Mr. Tanier has finally picked the Packers to lose; maybe that means they'll finally look like a winning team on Sunday! I'm not putting any money on it, though. The most fitting descriptors for Green Bay this year are "underwhelming," "injured," and "penalty-prone." All of the pundits who picked them to win the Super Bowl this year must be wondering what the heck happened! I sure am. In the meantime, at least Mr. Tanier can make me laugh about it.

I've had long hair since I was 16 - and I turned 63 two days ago. I can trim the ends myself and wash it every second week. When I garden it is easier to tie back than short hair - and at least once a month a total stranger will stop me to say they love my beautiful (red) hair. It is undoubtably a rebellion against my father, who decided I should have a "proper" hairstyle when I was 12 or 13 and then cut off one of my braids to end the argument. But I enjoy it - it's me - and I wouldn't dream of being apologetic for it. The right to be ourselves rather than some cookie-cutter version of a woman was what feminism was all about (I was there - I remember) so let's let our individuality shine in appreciation for the struggles that it took to achieve that freedom.

Nearly 70 now and with thinning hair. I tried to grow it long one last time for the number of styling options it brought, but it was just to sparse and "pulled" down my face in an unattractive way. Kiddos to those who can still get away with it; I've had to settle for a mid-length bob that I can tease out in order to look a little untamed. Ain't dead yet, no sirree!

Like very much comments by Charles & James. Work well done & helpful understanding our wars. The contrast our prisoners or detainees of war vs prisoners our state prisons, Federal prisons & detention centers might be revealing; perhaps lessening the violence.

John: I viewed your "Memorial Day in Arlington National Cemetery" . Its everything you intended. A solace some, such sacrifice so many, our country, Afghanistan, Iraq. Peace.

Lovely article. And I enjoyed the comments too. I'm 57 and have shoulder length dyed hair, which is more work and expense than the plain wash and wear long hair I wore for my first 40 or so years. Though I liked the plain straight beige blonde long hair of my earlier years, I came to really detest the long straight grey hair of my later years, so the dying and cutting and styling is worthwhile to me. But it's got to have a natural look to it; I don't know anyone who wants the purple white short doo that we so often see on older women.

As disturbing as many of these pictures are, I still can't get over #13- Steroid Jesus Deluxe surrounded by a whirling dervish of superheroes and heavily armed avatars. The complete and utter distortion and disintegration of the "love your enemy, turn the other cheek" guy. Phenomenal...

I'm bothered how this so-called document dump is so closely co-ordinated with major news outlets. Much to slick for my liking. If Wikileaks is really going to do a document dump, then do just that.. and THEN let the media, bloggers, and whomever else do their analysis.

The way this is coming out just doesn't sit well.
who is going to judge these war crimes??

Its interesting that progressives and enlightened citizens see Wikileaks as serving a valuable purpose and worthy of a Nobel Peace Prize while most of those on the right condemn it for telling the truth. The Left desires Truth and Justice and conservatives prefer Lies and Imperialism. That more than any other distinction defines American politics and the divisiveness that now defines our age.

Lest anyone want to slap the hand of the New York Times....this story has been on the front webpage of every single media outlet I can think of in the world, both print and cable t.v. and web only news all evening...eliminating the New York Times from your browser is not going to make it go away, and it is comforting that all media outlets are united in publishing this...no one single organization is in fact sticking its neck out, since they all published simultaneously, and in solidarity...
The dead deserve no less than our witnessing, and determination to not let unjustified wars continued to be waged with our name and tax dollars.

“Rome Illuminated brings Rome and its history to life!”
Oct 7, 2010 FLtravel65

Our guide from Rome Illuminated, Evan Firestone, designed wonderful walking tours of Rome at night, the Vatican (and Vatican museum) and the Coliseum/Forum. Evan's knowledge of the various attractions brought them to life for us and he had scheduled the tours at times when the crowds were the smallest (a difficult task during the busy summer months). A friend recommended Evan as the perfect tour guide for Rome and he surpassed all of our expectations. We would not visit Rome again without booking Evan and Rome Illuminated.
